title: Mum heartbroken after husband went out on bike ride, had heart attack and never came back
text:
Mum heartbroken after husband went out on bike ride, had heart attack and never came back Karen Sutton was left devastated when her partner Simon never came back from a bike ride   Share   Comments By Lily Pattison Nicholas Bieber 16:22, 2 FEB 2017 News Karen Sutton now wants to help the charity that supported her children following their dad's death (Photo: Just Giving / Karen Sutton)   Share   Comments Get daily   A mum-of-two was left heartbroken after her husband went out on a routine bike ride, only to never return home.
Simon Sutton left his home in Cheltenham in Gloucestershire in September but sometime along the journey he had a heart attack and died.
The 43-year-old, who has previously completed three London marathons, left behind his devastated wife Karen and two daughters Sydney, nine, and Ella, five.
But now Karen is finding the strength to pay tribute to Simon in the name of mud and charity.
Read More Inspiring blind teen completes brutal Tough Mudder obstacle course - smashing records and perceptions "The first few days after Simon died I was just in shock, on another planet," Karen, who works at Cheltenham General Hospital, told Gloucestershire Live . 
"You just don't know what to do – it's a situation you never imagine yourself in."
Five months on, Karen says she is finally finding her strength again - and is now planning to put that to the test in memory of her partner.
Hoping to raise money for charity Winston's Wish, which supported her children through their loss, she will be taking on Tough Mudder.
The exhausting obstacle course of mud in Henley-upon-Thames will see her run for five miles, and climb over 13 large obstacles.
Read More 10 reasons why YOU should do a Tough Mudder race And she won't be doing it alone - despite originally arranging a team of four - as 50 friends and family will be joining her on the course in April.
"I'm astounded," she said. "With 50 of us it will be fun, but very emotional. People have been really supportive of me and my family – I am so lucky in so many ways. My friends and family have really rallied around."
Describing how much help her kids received from Winston's Wish, Karen said: "They helped us with advice for the children and helped take them to the funeral home to involve them in the situation.
"They were just talking to them in the right way and giving all the advice that I really needed to know.
"They even picked us up as a family to take us to one on one counselling.
"They are there if you have ever got a question, and were just so lovely and kind."
If you would like to donate to Karen's cause, you can visit https://www.justgiving.com/fundraising/Suttons-soldiers
